channel.title: Nature Materials
channel.description: Nature Materials is a multidisciplinary journal aimed at bringing together cutting-edge research across the entire spectrum of materials science and technology. Nature Materials covers all applied and fundamental aspects of the synthesis/processing, structure/composition, properties and performance of materials. Nature Materials provides a forum for the development of a common identity among materials scientists while encouraging researchers to cross established subdisciplinary lines. To achieve this, Nature Materials takes an interdisciplinary, integrated and balanced approach to all areas of materials research while fostering the exchange of ideas between scientists involved in different communities.
channel.dc:rights: © 2025 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Crystallographic guess-and-check
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 11 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02315-6

Machine learning is shown to help solve nanocrystalline structures from broadened powder X-ray diffraction patterns, but the underlying inference remains mathematically challenging.
item.dc:title: Crystallographic guess-and-check
item.dc:creator: N. Duane Loh

item.title: Mitigating proton trapping in cubic perovskite oxides via ScO<sub>6</sub> octahedral networks
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 08 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02311-w

Solid-state electrolytes that operate at a temperature of 300 °C suffer from a H+ concentration–conductivity trade-off. Here heavy Sc doping of cubic perovskites is shown to bypass this trade-off, enabling a proton conductivity of 0.01 S cm−1 that arises from rapid proton diffusion along ScO6 octahedra.
item.dc:title: Mitigating proton trapping in cubic perovskite oxides via ScO<sub>6</sub> octahedral networks
item.dc:creator: Kota Tsujikawa
Junji Hyodo
Susumu Fujii
Kazuki Takahashi
Yuto Tomita
Nai Shi
Yasukazu Murakami
Shusuke Kasamatsu
Yoshihiro Yamazaki

item.title: Reconfigurable magnetic order in 2D materials
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 04 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02304-9

Layer-dependent magnetic behaviour is used to realize reconfigurable exchange bias in a 2D antiferromagnet.
item.dc:title: Reconfigurable magnetic order in 2D materials
item.dc:creator: Paul Stevenson

item.title: Fatigue in metals and alloys
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 04 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02308-5

Fatigue-induced failures remain a critical challenge to the performance and reliability of metals and alloys due to their inherently complex and unpredictable nature. This Perspective highlights emerging frontiers in fatigue research, including key mechanistic insights, material designs for improving fatigue resistance and advances in fabrication, characterization and modelling techniques.
item.dc:title: Fatigue in metals and alloys
item.dc:creator: Qingsong Pan
Lei Lu

item.title: Engineering a light-induced metastable state
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 01 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02303-w

Investigation of a long-lived metallic state in a low-dimensional cuprate demonstrates a strategy for on-demand light-driven metastability.
item.dc:title: Engineering a light-induced metastable state
item.dc:creator: Wei-Sheng Lee

item.title: Low-noise hole spin qubits in germanium
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 01 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02307-6

Noise is a key source of decoherence that hinders the scaling of quantum computers. Suppressing disorder in epitaxially strained quantum wells in germanium/silicon germanium heterostructures reduces the noise experienced by hole spin qubits.
item.dc:title: Low-noise hole spin qubits in germanium
item.dc:creator: Danielle Holmes
